main event: Observation of an unusual celestial phenomenon at Maxwell Field, Montgomery, Alabama on the night of 23 June 1947 by multiple credible observers.
interesting points: The observed object appeared from the West, traveled at a high rate of speed, and changed direction frequently in a zig-zag course.
It appeared to be at a great height and was slightly greater than a star in brilliance.
There was no audible sound associated with the object.
The object's behaviors contradicted known aerodynamical laws, and no plausible explanation was offered for its actions.
The report mentions that two of the observers were rated pilots, and the other two were air intelligence officers.
sighted object: An unusual light with brilliance slightly greater than a star, traveling at high speeds and changing directions in a zig-zag course.
witnesses: Credible observers including rated pilots and air intelligence officers.
